{{Infobox international football competition | tourney_name = | year = 2008 | other_titles = | image = | size = | caption = | country = Fiji | dates = 8–14 June 2008 | num_teams = 7 | confederations = 1 | venues = 1 | cities = 1 | champion_other = {{futsal|SOL}} | count = 1 | second_other = {{futsal|TAH|name=Tahiti}} | third_other = {{futsal|VAN}} | fourth_other = {{futsal|NZL}} | matches = 21 | goals = 163 | attendance = | top_scorer = | player = | updated = 28 August 2008 | prevseason = [[2004 Oceanian Futsal Championship|2004]] | nextseason = [[2009 Oceanian Futsal Championship|2009]] }} The '''2008 [[OFC Futsal Championship]]''' was the fifth edition of the main international futsal tournament of the Oceanian region. It took place in [[Suva]], [[Fiji]] from 8 June to 14 June 2008. The tournament also acted as a qualifying tournament for the [[2008 FIFA Futsal World Cup]] in [[Brazil]]. The [[Solomon Islands national futsal team|Solomon Islands]] won the tournament, and qualified for the World Cup. This was the first [[OFC Futsal Championship]] tournament not to include [[Australia national futsal team|Australia]] as they left the [[Oceania Football Confederation|OFC]] to join the [[Asian Football Confederation]] in 2006. ==Championship== The seven participating teams played each on a single [[round-robin tournament|round-robin]] format. The top team of the group, the Solomon Islands, won the championship and got a ticket to [[2008 FIFA Futsal World Cup|2008 Futsal World Cup]] in Brazil. {| style=border-collapse:collapse border=1 {{Infobox event | title = 2017 Turin stampede | image = Map - IT - Torino - Municipality code 1272.svg | caption = Location of [[Turin]] in Italy | time = 10:30 p.m. | date = {{Start date|2017|06|03|df=y}} | place = [[Turin]], [[Italy]] | coordinates = | cause = Robbery attempt and a loud bang | reported death(s) = 1 | injuries = 1,526 }}
The '''2017 Turin stampede''' occurred on 3 June 2017 when panic emerged after a robbery attempt during a screening of the [[2017 UEFA Champions League Final|UEFA Champions League Final]] in [[Turin]], [[Italy]] between Torinese club [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] and [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]]. One woman died,<ref>{{cite news |last=Pottingham |first=Robert |title=Juventus pay tribute after a 38-year-old woman dies from injuries sustained during the Turin Champions League final fanzone stampede |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-4609264/Juventus-supporter-dies-following-Turin-fanzone-stampede.html |access-date=April 1, 2018 |newspaper=[[Mail Online]] |date=June 15, 2017}}</ref><ref name=dead>{{cite news |url=http://www.lastampa.it/2017/06/15/cronaca/morta-la-donna-travolta-in-piazza-san-carlo-bkJM9nTjn3yr2mYmU1aziK/pagina.html |title= Morta la donna travolta in piazza San Carlo |newspaper=[[La Stampa]] |date=June 15, 2017 |access-date=June 15, 2017 |language=it |location=Torino}}</ref> and at least 1,526 people were injured.<ref name="BNO1">{{cite news |url=http://bnonews.com/news/index.php/news/id5974 |title=Panic erupts during Champions League viewing in Italy, injuring 1,000 |date=June 4, 2017 |work=[[BNO News]] |access-date=June 4, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170603223951/http://bnonews.com/news/index.php/news/id5974 |archive-date=2017-06-03 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Stampede== The incident occurred at approximately 10:30 p.m. local time, about 10 minutes before the end of the match, when [[panic]] erupted among those at [[Piazza San Carlo]], leading to a stampede. During the panic, a railing of stairs leading to an underground parking garage gave way, causing additional injuries.
Although the panic was initially thought to be caused by the noise of [[firecracker]]s, it was later determined to be caused by a robbery attempt of shooting [[pepper spray]] into the crowd to steal valuables among the public,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.thelocal.it/20180413/eight-arrested-turin-football-stampede-piazza-san-carlo |title=Eight arrested for sparking deadly Turin football stampede |date=April 13, 2018 |access-date=April 15, 2018 |work=[[The Local]]}}</ref> and someone shouting that a bomb had gone off may have fueled the panic.<ref name="AFP1">{{cite news |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/30-injured-juventus-fan-panic-bomb-scare-214824769--sow.html |title=200 injured in Juventus fan panic after bomb scare: police |date=June 4, 2017 |agency=[[Agence France-Presse]] |access-date=June 4, 2017 |work=[[Yahoo Sports]] |location=Turin}}</ref>
After the stampede and a subsequent evacuation, the square was left strewn with sneakers which were ripped off people's feet as they ran.<ref name="AFP1" />
On 13 April 2018, eight people were arrested on charges of triggering mass panic to commit a robbery using pepper spray. One of them confessed the crime. The suspects were identified by telephone interceptions, in one of which a gold necklace stolen in the event was mentioned.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.ansa.it/english/news/2018/04/13/eight-arrested-for-causing-turin-soccer-stampede-4_86e9c6e5-d33a-42b0-9b2a-bc84b344dbc3.html |title=Eight arrested for causing Turin soccer stampede |author=Redazione |date=April 13, 2018 |access-date=April 15, 2018 |work=[[Agenzia Nazionale Stampa Associata]]}}</ref>
==Casualties== At least 1,527 people were injured, including seven who were seriously injured.<ref name="ANSA1">{{cite news |url=http://www.ansa.it/sito/notizie/cronaca/2017/06/03/finale-champions-panico-a-torino-tra-tifosi-juve_564ee58c-6978-4719-ace4-75af8a6cf378.html |title=Champions, panico a Torino, 1.527 feriti, tre sono gravi |date=June 4, 2017 |work=[[Agenzia Nazionale Stampa Associata]] |access-date=June 4, 2017 |language=it |last=Di Marco |first=Alessandro}}</ref> On 15 June, less than two weeks after the stampede, a 38-year-old woman, Erika Pioletti, died in hospital of her sustained injuries while another woman, Marisa Amato, became [[tetraplegic]].<ref name=dead/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://torino.repubblica.it/cronaca/2018/04/25/news/torino-194769542/|title=Torino, il 5 mille per aiutare nonna Marisa paralizzata dalla folla di piazza San Carlo|publisher=repubblica.it|date=25 April 2018|language=Italian}}</ref>
==Reactions== Some older Juventus fans said the stampede had evoked painful memories of the [[Heysel Stadium disaster]] in 1985, when 39 fans, mostly Juventus supporters from Italy, were crushed against a collapsing wall in [[Brussels]], [[Belgium]], before the start of a match between Juventus and [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]].<ref name="AFP1" />
In November 2017 the Prosecutor Office of Turin started a formal investigation involving around twenty suspects, included the mayor [[Chiara Appendino]] and the police chief Angelo Sanna.<ref>{{cite news |title=Disastro colposo. Venti indagati per piazza San Carlo |url=http://www.lastampa.it/2017/11/07/italia/cronache/disastro-colposo-venti-indagati-per-piazza-san-carlo-jqySOtG9e5CAeccg23BCoL/pagina.html |newspaper=[[La Stampa]] |access-date=April 10, 2018 |language=it |date=November 7, 2017 |last=Numa |first=Massimo |last2=Rossi |first2=Andrea |location=Torino}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Use British English|date=May 2013}} [[File:DarleyMoorAirfield.jpg|thumb|right|Darley Moor Airfield from above]] '''Airways Airsports''' is based at [[Darley Moor Airfield]], [[Derbyshire]], is the only airpark in the [[United Kingdom]] offering [[hang gliding]], [[paragliding]], [[paramotoring]] and [[microlight]] training and [[Aviation|flying]]. It is a [[British Hang Gliding and Paragliding Association]] and [[British Microlight Aircraft Association| British Microlight Aircraft Association (BMAA)]] recognised school. Instructors include a [[Judy Leden|three-times world champion]], world record holders, British cross country champion, British distance record holder, Royal Aeroclub gold medal winner and members of the British hang gliding and paragliding team.<ref>{{cite web | publisher = Airways Airsports | title = Instructor information | date = 2010-03-26 | url = http://www.airways-airsports.com/showkb.php?org_id=516&kb_header_id=304&kb_id=456 | accessdate = 2011-04-17 }}</ref>
Airways also teach paragliding, hang gliding, paramotoring and microlight flying at BHPA and BMAA schools in the [[Alps]].<ref>{{cite web | publisher = Airways Airsports | title = Airways Airsports France | date = 2010-03-26 | url = http://www.notanant.com/showtopic.php?org_id=11891&kb_header_id=29691 | accessdate = 2011-04-18 }}</ref>
== Teaching methods ==
===Hang gliding=== [[File:Hg rheinebene aug2000.jpg|thumb|right|Hang glider in mid air.]] [[Hang gliding]] teaching is primarily through [[tandem]] [[Aerotow#Aerotowing|aerotow]] flights with take off and landing both on wheels. The student and instructor clip into a tandem glider side by side and attach themselves and the glider to a tow line pulled by a high powered 'tug' microlight. The tandem hang glider is then towed to around 3000' with the instructor and student keeping in line behind the microlight. At the top of the tow the line is released and the student is taken through a number of exercises before landing the glider under instruction. Once the student has completed a number of exercises and demonstrated an ability to keep the [[Hang glider|glider]] in line behind the microlight on tow, and land safely, then the student progresses on to a solo, wheeled hang glider. Once a student has completed a number of solo flights and demonstrated safe tows and landings solo then they are awarded their Club Pilot Certificate (aerotow) and can progress to flying in a club rather than a school environment. Airways have developed a wheeled solo [[Hang glider|glider]] for the initial solo flights.<ref>{{cite web | publisher = Airways Airsports | title = Hang gliding training | date = 2010-03-26 | url = http://www.airways-airsports.com/showkb.php?org_id=516&kb_header_id=241&kb_id=431 | accessdate = 2011-04-18 }}</ref>
===Paragliding=== [[File:Paraglider towed launch.jpg|thumb|right|Paraglider towed launch]] Airways train [[Aviator|pilots]] using a static winch for [[Paraglider#Towed launch|paragliding training]]. Compared to [[Paraglider#Learning to fly|training on the hill]] this is a faster and less physically demanding way to try out [[paragliding]] as Darley Moor airfield is big enough for the winch to be moved around if the wind changes.<ref>{{cite web |publisher=BHPA |title=Paragliding |date=2010-03-26 |url=http://www.bhpa.co.uk/paraglide/index.php |accessdate=2011-04-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722040821/http://www.bhpa.co.uk/paraglide/index.php |archivedate=22 July 2011 }}</ref>
The course or taster starts with a full demonstration/walkthrough of the equipment, the winch commands/release etc. and how to use the radio. Students are then trained to [[Paraglider#Launching|ground-handle]] the wing, then the flying starts with some short low level flights before progressing to basic manoeuvres and on to high flying circuits.<ref>{{cite web | publisher = Airways Airsports | title = Learn Paragliding | date = 2010-03-26 | url = http://www.airways-airsports.com/showkb.php?org_id=516&kb_header_id=242&kb_id=1135 | accessdate = 2011-04-18 }}</ref>
===Hill conversion=== By using a combination of aerotow and winch for training, pilots gain the skills necessary for flying in a club environment with winch or aerotow launching. With a hill conversion course pilots can be trained to fly from hills. Airways primarily use the Derbyshire Soaring Club sites. There are hills to suit all wind directions for both hang gliding and paragliding.<ref>{{cite web | publisher = Airways Airsports | title = Paragliding Conversions | date = 2010-03-26 | url = http://www.airways-airsports.com/showkb.php?org_id=516&kb_header_id=242&kb_id=448 | accessdate = 2011-04-18 }}</ref>
===Paramotoring and powered hang gliding=== [[File:Mike Fifield CA 2007.jpg|thumb|right|Two powered paragliders in flight]] [[File:WikipediaHangmotor.jpg|thumb|right|A powered hang glider]] Paramotoring training starts with standard paragliding training on the winch before the introduction of the engine and training with power.<ref>{{cite web | publisher = Airways Airsports | title = Learn to fly a Paramotor | date = 2010-03-26 | url = http://www.airways-airsports.com/showkb.php?org_id=516&kb_header_id=306&kb_id=442 | accessdate = 2011-04-18 }}</ref> Similarly training for [[Powered hang glider|powered hang gliding]] involves learning to fly a hang glider first before conversion to power.<ref>{{cite web | publisher = Airways Airsports | title = Powered Hang Gliding | date = 2010-03-26 | url = http://www.airways-airsports.com/showkb.php?org_id=516&kb_header_id=241&kb_id=433 | accessdate = 2011-04-18 }}</ref>
===Single seat microlight flying=== Either flying with a paragliding wing in a [[Powered paragliding#Trikes and powered parachutes|wheeled, powered buggy]] or in a single seat wheeled powered hang glider.
===Microlighting=== [[File:comco ikarus c42 g-hbbh kemble arp.jpg|thumb|right|[[Ikarus C42]], a German microlight]] The school aircraft available for training are as follows; *[[Fixed-wing aircraft|Fixed wing]]: **[[Ikarus C42]] [[Microlight#Types of aircraft|(3-Axis)]] **Snowbird (3-Axis modified to be fully flown with hand controls)<ref>{{cite web | publisher = Airways Airsports | title = Disabled Microlight Aviation | date = 2010-03-26 | url = http://www.flyozoneuk.com/showkb.php?org_id=516&kb_header_id=303&kb_id=441&full=full&edit= | accessdate = 2011-04-18 }}</ref> [[File:Pegasus quantum 15-912 microlight g-byff kemble arp.jpg|thumb|right|Pegasus Quantum 145-912 microlight trike]] [[File:quik gt450 ultralight g-gttp arp.jpg|thumb|right|P and M Aviation Quik GT450 microlight]] *[[Ultralight trike|Flex wing]]: **Quantum 912 **[[P&M GT450|GT450]] (Flex-wing)
==Darley Moor Airfield facilities==
The [[Darley Moor Airfield|airfield]] has ample parking with full wheelchair and vehicle access. In the clubhouse there are male, female and disabled, showers, light refreshments, a shop and in 2011 a brand new hangar has been built.<ref>{{cite web | publisher = Airways Airsports | title = Paragliding Conversions | date = 2011-01-20 | url = http://www.facebook.com/media/set/fbx/?set=a.440735164104.198635.195724634104 | accessdate = 2011-04-18 }}</ref>
The school offers the widest range of disabled free flight facilities of any school in the UK, using specially modified equipment to fly hang gliders, paragliders and microlight aircraft. The school has close links with the [[Aerobility]] (formerly the British Disabled Flying Association) and [[Flyability]] – charities offering support, advice and scholarships to disabled people wishing to experience or learn to fly.
==Media coverage== Airways Airsports has been chosen by the press to fly or teach presenters and journalists
(2003) ''[[Blue Peter]]'' presenter [[Matt Baker (television personality)|Matt Baker]] taught to fly and makes successful tandem world record breaking flight with Airways instructor [[Judy Leden]].<ref>{{cite news | publisher = BBC | title = Hang-gliders break world record | date = 2002-10-15 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/2331253.stm | accessdate = 2011-04-18 }}</ref>
(2006) An extract from [[BBC|BBC's]] Great British Summer. Airways instructor [[Judy Leden]] flying Tandem with [[Cloud Appreciation Society]] founder [[Gavin Pretor-Pinney]], showing him what its like to fly through the clouds on a hang glider.<ref>{{cite news | publisher = BBC | title = Great British Summer | date = 2006-11-05 | url = https://www.facebook.com/video/video.php?v=10150268749815135&oid=195724634104&comments | accessdate = 2011-05-17 }}</ref>
(2010) [[Geologist]] [[Iain Stewart (geologist)|Iain Stewart]] flown over a waterfall in a paramotor buggy by Airways CFI [[Chris Dawes (Pilot)|Chris Dawes]].<ref>{{cite web | publisher = BBC | title = Icelandic Paragliding: Behind the scenes | date = 2010-01-19 | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p0062dqy | accessdate = 2011-04-18 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | publisher = IMDB | title = Chris Dawes | date = 2010-01-19 | url = https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3785086/ | accessdate = 2011-04-18 }}</ref>
(2010) ''[[Country Tracks]]'' presenter [[Ellie Harrison (journalist)|Ellie Harrison]] flew above Derbyshire with Airways instructor [[Andy Snell]].<ref>{{cite web | publisher = BBC | title = Country Tracks | date = 2010-09-02 | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00tn9ht | accessdate = 2011-04-18 }}</ref>
(2010) ''[[Blue Peter]]'' presenter [[Joel Defries]] learnt to fly with Airways instructor [[Judy Leden]] with the aim of flying with Lucy the [[peregrine falcon]].<ref>{{cite web | publisher = BBC | title = Blue Peter | date = 2010-10-04 | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b006md2v/episodes/2010 | accessdate = 2011-04-18 }}</ref>
(2010) ''[[BBC Breakfast]]'' sports presenter [[Mike Bushell]] and ''[[BBC Disability Sport]]'' reporter [[Tony Garrett]] flew tandem with Airways instructor [[Judy Leden]] to experience hang gliding and to demonstrate the benefits of aerotowing for disabled students.<ref>{{cite news | publisher = BBC | title = Mike Bushell flies high with aerotow hang-gliding | date = 2010-10-08 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/disability_sport/9075500.stm | accessdate = 2011-04-18 }}</ref>
(2011) ''[[The Gadget Show]]'' presenter, [[Jon Bentley (TV presenter)|Jon Bentley]], flew with [[Judy Leden]], competing with a [[peregrine falcon]] to track a lure<ref>{{cite web | publisher = Gadget Show | title = Episode 11 (Man Vs Beast Challenge) | date = 2011-04-25 | url = http://www.channel5.com/shows/the-gadget-show/episodes/episode-11-158 | accessdate = 2011-04-26 }}</ref>
(2011) [[Judy Leden]] takes [[BBC Breakfast]] Weather reporter [[Carol Kirkwood]] flying in a hang glider to see a cloud close up and weight it, for BBC's [[The Great British Weather Show]].<ref>{{cite web | publisher = BBC | title = A clip from episode 2 'Carol Kirkwood flies through clouds' | date = 2011-06-20 | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p00jc083 | accessdate = 2011-09-08 }}</ref>
(2011) [[Gethin Jones]] gets taken up flying in a microlight by Airways CFI [[Chris Dawes (Pilot)|Chris Dawes]] in a microlight for ITV's "[[The Adventurer's Guide to Britain]]", to get a unique birds eye view of the Peak District.<ref>{{cite web |publisher=ITV |title=Episode 1 'The Adventurer's Guide to Britain' |date=2011-11-22 |url=http://www.itv.com/itvplayer/video/?Filter=290424 |accessdate=2011-09-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111124112159/http://www.itv.com/itvplayer/video/?Filter=290424 |archivedate=24 November 2011 }}</ref>

{{Other uses|Andorinha (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox football club| clubname = Andorinha| nickname = | image = [[Image:Andorinha SC.png|250px]]| fullname = Andorinha Sporting Club| founded = 1931 | ground = [[Estádio Nacional 12 de Julho]]
[[São Tomé Island]], [[São Tomé and Príncipe]]| capacity = 6,500| chairman = | manager = | league = [[São Tomé and Príncipe Championship]]| season = 2014/15| position = Second Division| pattern_la1=_ukr10a|pattern_b1=_ukr10a|pattern_ra1=_ukr10a|pattern_sh1=_ukr10h|pattern_so1=_ukr10a| leftarm1=|body1=|rightarm1=|shorts1=|socks1=ffffff| pattern_la2=_ukr10h|pattern_b2=_ukr10h|pattern_ra2=_ukr10h|pattern_sh2=_ukr10a|pattern_so2=_ukr10h| leftarm2=|body2=|rightarm2=|shorts2=|socks2=ffffff }} '''Andorinha Sport Club''' is a [[football (soccer)|football]] club that plays in the [[São Tomé and Príncipe Championship]]. The team is based in the neighbourhood of [[Ponta Mina]] near [[Praia Cruz]] in the island of [[São Tomé Island|São Tomé]]. ==History== The club was founded in 1931 and is one of the oldest sport clubs in the nation. The team won their first colonial title in the 1938, in 1970, Andorinha won five straight provincial titles. Andorinha won their last provincial title in 1973, two years before São Tomé and Príncipe gained independence. 1968/69 season. In 1984, Andorinha won their first title after independence and is the fourth team in history to do so and is the only title won by the team. In 1981, the club celebrated its 50th anniversary, in 2006, it celebrated its 75th anniversary of foundation. Andorinha was finished and deprived of continuing in the island Premier Division in 2010,[http://www.rsssf.com/tabless/saotome09.html São Tomé and Príncipe 2009/10] José Batalha & RSSSF.com the club competed in the second division between 2011 and 2014 until they were deprived of continuing after being in the last two places[http://www.rsssf.com/tabless/saotome14.html São Tomé e Príncipe 2014] José Batalha & RSSSF.com and since 2015, Andorinha competes in the third division. ==Stadium== [[File:Sao Tome National Stadium (15626686954).jpg|thumb|right|350px|Esádio Nacional 12 de Julho, home field of Sporting Praia Cruz]][[Estádio Nacional 12 de Julho]] is a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[São Tomé]], [[São Tomé and Príncipe]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches. The stadium holds 6,500. Its address is Avenidas das Nações Unidas. The stadium is home to the three best football clubs in the nation and the island including [[Sporting Praia Cruz]], [[Futebol Club Aliança Nacional|Aliança Nacional]], Andorinha and [[Vitória FC (Riboque)|Vitória Riboque]]. The club also trains and practices at the stadium. ==Logo and uniform== Its logo features a white crest (of the neighbourhood) with ASC on top then left and right. Its home uniform are colored blue with a yellow short. {{Football kit box | align = | pattern_la = | pattern_b = _whitevertical | pattern_ra = | leftarm = 0000FF | body = 0000FF | rightarm = 0000FF | shorts = FFFF00 | socks = 0000FF | title = Home uniform up to 2016 }} ==Honours== *'''[[São Tomé and Príncipe Championship]]s: 8''' ::'''Before independence: 7''' :::1938, 1965, 1967, 1968, 1968/69, 1970, 1973 ::'''Since independence: 1''' :::1984 *'''[[São Tomé and Príncipe Cup]]: 3''' **'''Before independence:''' :::1960, 1967, 1970 *'''[[São Tomé Island League]]: 8''' ::'''Before independence: 7''' :::1938, 1965, 1967, 1968, 1968/69, 1970, 1973 ::'''Since independence: 1''' :::1984 ==League and cup history== ===Positions=== *10th (2015) - Third Division ===Statistics=== *'''Best position:''' 1st (national) *'''Appearances at the National Championships:''' **'''National:''' 1 ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://andorinha.bloguedesporto.com/21660/Andorinha-Sport-Club-campeao-de-S-Tome-68-69/ Blog of Andorinha Sporting Club, by Alvaro Nogueira, former player of team] {{pt icon}} {{São Tomé League}} {{Água Grande}} [[Category:Andorinha Sport Club| ]] [[Category:Football clubs in São Tomé and Príncipe]] [[Category:Sport in São Tomé]] [[Category:São Tomé Island Third Division]] [[Category:1931 establishments in São Tomé and Príncipe]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 1931]]

'''Blanik''' is the name of a technique in [[vault (gymnastics)|vault]] in [[artistic gymnastics]], a double front [[handspring (gymnastics)|handspring]] vault in piked position in, followed by a double back [[Tsukahara (vault)|Tsukahara]]. The piked performance of the technique has rating 10.0 in the [[Code of Points (artistic gymnastics)|Code of Points]]. The vault was first performed by the [[Poland|Polish]] [[artistic gymnastics|gymnast]] [[Leszek Blanik]], and is named after him.<ref name=fig-blanik>{{cite web |url=http://exel.fig-gymnastics.com/events/athletes/bio.jsp?ID=227 |title=Leszek Blanik |publisher=[[International Federation of Gymnastics]] |accessdate=14 September 2008 }}</ref><ref name=ig-blanik>{{cite web |url=http://www.intlgymnast.com/olympics/gymnasts/Poland/578.html |title=Leszek Blanik |work=International Gymnast |accessdate=14 September 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821162817/http://www.intlgymnast.com/olympics/gymnasts/Poland/578.html |archivedate=2008-08-21}}</ref> Leszek Blanik was the [[2007 World Artistic Gymnastics Championships|world champion in vault 2007]], and [[Gymnastics at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Men's vault|Olympic champion in vault in 2008]].<ref name=sports-ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/bl/leszek-blanik-1.html |title=Leszek Blanik |work=Olympics at Sports-Reference.com |publisher=[[Sports Reference LLC]] |accessdate=26 December 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714023534/http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/bl/leszek-blanik-1.html# |archivedate=2011-07-14 |df= }}</ref>

revision.text:
{{Infobox non-profit | name = Fédération camerounaise des sports pour personnes handicapées | image = | type = | tax_id = | founded_date =1998 | founder = | location = Yaounde, Cameroon | coordinates = | origins = | key_people ='''Chairman''': Abeng Mbozo'o | area_served = Cameroon | focus = Sport, Disability | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members =4: [[Federation of Disabled Sport of Cameroon]], [[Sports Association of Blind and Partially Sighted of Cameroon]] (ASAMC), [[National League Sports for the Deaf in Cameroon]] (LINASCAM), and [[Special Olympics Cameroon]]. | owner = | non-profit_slogan = | former name = | homepage = | dissolved = August 2011 | footnotes = <!--Member of [[International Sports Federation for Persons with Intellectual Disability]]--> }}
'''Cameroonian Sports Federation for People with Disabilities (FECASH)''' (French: ''{{Lang|en|Fédération camerounaise des sports pour personnes handicapées (Fécash)}}'') was one of the primary national sports federation for people with disabilities in Cameroon prior to the organization being dissolved in August 2011. It served as the country's [[National Paralympic Committee]] for many years. Problems with internal governance arose starting in the early 2000s and continued until the federation closed.
FECASH was one of the organizations to support the introduction of goalball in Cameroon. They also participated in United Nations' International Day of Persons with Disabilities activities.
== Governance == Cameroonian Sports Federation for People with Disabilities (FECASH) was created in 1998 for people with a variety of different types of disabilities. The federation was based on [[Douala|Doula]], and had four member organizations: [[Federation of Disabled Sport of Cameroon]],<ref group="translations">The name of the organization in French is, ''{{Lang|fr|Fédération des Handicapés Sportifs du Cameroun}}''.</ref> [[Sports Association of Blind and Partially Sighted of Cameroon]] (ASAMC),<ref group="translations">The name of the organization in French is, ''{{Lang|fr|Association Sportive des Aveugles et Malvoyants du Cameroun}}''.</ref> [[National League Sports for the Deaf in Cameroon]] (LINASCAM),<ref group="translations">The name of the organization in French is, ''{{Lang|fr|Ligue Nationale des Sports pour Sourds au Cameroun}}''.</ref> and [[Special Olympics Cameroon]]. The offices for the Federation from 1998 to early 2010 were at the personal residence of [[Abeng Mbozo'o]], a non-disabled Cameroon doctor. Mbozo'o served as the organizations chairman, with each of the member federations being represented with a Vice President position in FECASH.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.yanous.com/pratique/sports-loisirs/sportsloisirs100416.html|title=Handisports et loisirs : Handisport au Cameroun.|last=Bih|first=Muluh Hilda|last2=Soué|first2=Emilienne|date=April 2010|website=Yanous!|publisher=Yanous!|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 6, 2016}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.cameroonvoice.com/news/article-sport-495.html|title=Comité international paralympique : Le Cameroun menacé de radiation|last=Biwol|first=Ateba|date=July 23, 2009|website=Cameroon Voice|publisher=Cameroon Voice|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 2, 2016}}</ref>
=== History of governance === {{See also|Cameroon at the 2008 Summer Paralympics}} For a long while, the organization was largely run by the president after all the members resigned.<ref name=":0" /> During its early history, FECASH had trouble securing funding. For three years, they had an annual government grant of 4.5 million [[West African CFA franc|XOF]] (€6.854). After the initial three years, government terminated the subsidy.<ref name=":1" />
FECASH was founded in 1998, and became affiliated with the [[International Paralympic Committee]] (IPC). At the time, the President of FECASH did not seek government approval prior to affiliating with the IPC. FECASH's original president subsequently moved to Japan. In 2004, a former FECASH Vice-President created a new NPC for Cameroon without approval from the government. He subsequently moved to the [[United States]]. In the late 2000s, a third NPC for Cameroon was then created after that called [[Cameroon Paralympic Club]] (CPC)<ref group="translations">The name of the organization in French is, ''{{Lang|fr|Club paralympique camerounai}}''.</ref> which also failed to get government approval before trying to become the IPC recognized NPC. The CPC was led by President [[Etienne Songa]]. Songa challenged the government's claim of failure for recognition. Songa claimed that FECASH, as a result of owing the IPC money, had notified the IPC that the Cameroon Paralympic Club should be recognized as the NPC for Cameroon. Songa's statements were supported by CPC Technical Director [[Jean-Marie Aléokol Mabiemé]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.news.mboa.info/sport-pour-tous/fr/content/actualite/57841,jeux-paralympiques-2008-le-cameroun-absent-pour-desordre/0,0/4389.html|title=Sport pour tous — Jeux paralympiques 2008 : Le Cameroun absent pour désordre|last=|first=|date=September 11, 2008|website=Mboa.info|publisher=Mboa.info|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 7, 2016}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://www.news.mboa.info/sport-pour-tous/fr/content/actualite/15372,jeux-paralympiques-le-cameroun-absent-a-beijing/0,0/4389.html|title=Sport pour tous — Jeux paralympiques : Le Cameroun absent à Beijing|last=|first=|date=September 9, 2008|website=Mboa.info|publisher=Mboa.info|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 7, 2016}}</ref> FECASH had other issues in the late 2000s and early 2010s. Having statues was a then requirement of the International Paralympic Committee to be a member of the IPC in good standing. FECASH lacked governing statues in 2008.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3"/><ref name=":3" /> These problems related to internal governance were one of the reasons why Cameroon was unable to inscribe any participants for the [[2008 Summer Paralympics]].<ref name=":2" />
FECASH was restructured in March 2011,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.yanous.com/pratique/sports-loisirs/sportsloisirs130906.html|title=Yanous ! Handisport : Des Jeux francophones inégaux.|last=Mbogo|first=Etienne|last2=Assoumaïla|first2=Ali|date=September 2013|website=Yanous!|publisher=Yanous!|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 7, 2016|last3=Lejard|first3=Laurent}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://french.peopledaily.com.cn/Sports/7577489.html|title=Cameroun : élection du président du comité national paralympique-Le Quotidien du Peuple en ligne|last=|first=|date=August 23, 2011|website=People's Daily (China)|publisher=|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 8, 2016}}</ref> before being dissolved in July 2011 as a result of Law No. 2011-18 of 15 July 2011 related to the organization and promotion of Physical and Sporting Activities. It was replaced by the [[Cameroonian Sports Federation for the Visually Impaired]] (FECASDEV),<ref group="translations">The name of the organization in French is, ''{{Lang|fr|Fédération camerounaise de Football (Fécafoot)}}''.</ref> the [[Cameroonian Sports Federation for the Physically Disabled]] (FECASDEP),<ref group="translations">The name of the organization in French is, ''{{Lang|fr|Fédération Camerounaise de Sports pour Déficients Physiques}}''.</ref> [[Cameroonian Federation of Sports the Intellectually Disabled]] (FECASDI)<ref group="translations">The name of the organization in French is, ''{{Lang|fr|Federation Camerounaise Des Sports Pour Deficients Intellectuals}}''.</ref> and the [[Cameroonian Sports Federation for the Deaf]] (FECASSO).<ref group="translations">The name of the organization in French is, ''{{Lang|fr|Fédération Camerounaise de Sports pour Sourds}}''.</ref> These four organizations were thane made members of the newly reformed [[Cameroonian Paralympic Committee]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.camerounparalympique.org/notre-organisation/|title=Notre Organisation — International Paralympic Committee|last=|first=|date=2016|website=Comité National Paralympique Camerounais (CNPC)|publisher=Comité National Paralympique Camerounais (CNPC)|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 5, 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161018205257/http://www.camerounparalympique.org/notre-organisation/|archivedate=October 18, 2016|df=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.yanous.com/news/rdpresse/rdpresse1103.html|title=Revue de presse internationale du handicap : Mars 2011.|last=|first=|date=March 2011|website=Yanous!|publisher=Yanous!|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 6, 2016}}</ref>
Before the organization's dissolution, Chairman Mbozo'o blamed some of the organization's failures on the Government Minister [[Pierre Ismaël Bidoung Mkpatt]] for appointing members to FECASH's board who then were completely absent from governing the organization. He also blamed the Government not providing funding to the organization.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.237online.com/article-19954-quatre-nouvelles-federations-sportives-bientot-au-cameroun.html|title=Quatre nouvelles fédérations sportives bientôt au Cameroun|last=|first=|date=March 18, 2011|work=|publisher=237online.com|newspaper=|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 7, 2016|via=}}</ref>
== History == FECASH supported the introduction of goalball in the country during the 2000s to diversify the number of sports available to people with vision impairments.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://reglo.org/posts/le-goalball-une-discipline-sportive-designee-pour-les-malvoyants-5289|title=Le Goalball : une discipline sportive désignée pour les malvoyants|last=Christelle|first=Manigang|date=December 2015|website=reglo.org|publisher=reglo.org|language=fr-fr|access-date=October 3, 2016}}</ref>
For the 2009 United Nations' International Day of Persons with Disabilities, FECASH organized nationwide sporting activities for people with disabilities. They held three regional wheelchair basketball tournaments, with the tournaments taking place in central Cameroon, southern Cameroon and coastal Cameroon. One of these tournaments took place in Douala, on the basketball courts of [[Military district|Military District]] 2. A goalball tournament also was organized at the Sports Palace in Yaounde. Deaf soccer, handball and basketball events also took place, with the [[Cameroon men's national deaf football team|Lions Indomptables Sourd]] playing a friendly match against a high school team from Nkomotou. The events also served as a celebration for the national delegation who went to [[Niamey]], [[Niger]] for the 2009 African Francophone Games for the Handicapped. The team returned having finished third in the overall medal count, winning 23 medals, 10 gold, 7 silver and 6 bronze.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.journalducameroun.com/article.php?aid=3356|title=Les sportifs handicapés se déploient au Cameroun|last=Gnotuom|first=Makeda Lydie|date=November 26, 2011|website=Journal Du Cameroun|publisher=Journal Du Cameroun|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 4, 2016}}</ref>
== Translations == {{reflist|group=translations}}
== References == {{Portal|Paralympics|Cameroon}} {{reflist|30em}}{{Disability sports in Cameroon}}

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Dandenong Stadium | nickname = | image = | location = [[Dandenong]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] | coordinates = {{Coord|-37.9641273|145.2262353|format=dms|type:landmark}} | broke_ground = 1991 | opened = 1992 | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = | construction_cost = | architect = | general_contractor = Britton Timbers - flooring{{cite web|title=Britton Timbers at Dandenong Stadium & Melbourne Sports and Aquatic Centre|url=http://www.brittontimbers.com.au/project/absolutely-floored|website=Britton Timbers Australia|accessdate=18 November 2017|language=en}} | former_names = | tenants = [[Dandenong Rangers]] ([[Women's National Basketball League|WNBL]]) (1992–present)
[[Dandenong Rangers (SEABL)|Dandenong Rangers]] ([[South East Australian Basketball League|SEABL]]) (2009–present) | seating_capacity = [[Basketball]]: 2,500{{cite web|title=Dandenong Stadium|url=http://www.austadiums.com/stadiums/stadiums.php?id=146|publisher=Austadiums|accessdate=19 June 2017}} | website = {{URL|http://www.dandenongstadium.com.au/|Dandenong Stadium}} |}} '''Dandenong Stadium''' is an Australian sports and entertainment centre in [[Dandenong]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]]. This stadium is home to the [[Women's National Basketball League|WNBL]]'s [[Dandenong Rangers]]. As of 7th November 2018, Nuru "Chocco Magic" Jammeh holds the single game record for most amount of three-point field goals made, with an astonishing 13/14 shooting. Until recently, this was also a world record, until Klay Thompson made 14/24. Basketball historians argue that Jammeh's feat was more impressive given the level of competition (Men's at Dandenong Stadium vs 2018 Chicago Bulls) and shooting percentage. '''Warning''' Due to unsafe access to facility, going in/out of Dandenong Basketball stadium by pedestrians are dangerous. This is due the fact that there is no pedestrians crossing near Dandenong Basketball stadium on Stud road (with 80km speed limit). The latest victim lost her life on 5th of April 2018, trying to cross the road. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Dandenong Rangers}} {{NBL Arenas}} {{WNBL Arenas}} [[Category:Basketball venues in Australia]] [[Category:Dandenong Rangers]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1992]] [[Category:Sports venues in Melbourne]] [[Category:Volleyball venues in Australia]]

[[FieldTurf]] (2009–present) | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[Kingston Colonials (baseball)|Kingston Colonials]] ([[Colonial League (baseball)|Colonial]]/[[Canadian–American League|Can-Am]]) (1949–1951)
[[Kingston High School Tigers]] ([[New York State Public High School Athletic Association|NYSPHSAA]]) (1952–present)
Hudson Valley Highlanders ([[North American Football League|NAFL]]) (2008)
[[Kingston Stockade Football Club (Stockade FC)|Kingston Stockade FC]] ([[National Premier Soccer League|NPSL]]) (2016–present) | seating_capacity = 1,500 |}} '''Robert Dietz Memorial Stadium''' is a football stadium in [[Kingston, New York]]. Dietz Stadium is the home field of the [[Kingston High School (New York)|Kingston High School]] Tigers football team. It is named for [[Robert H. Dietz]], a [[Medal of Honor]] recipient killed in World War II. Dietz was a Kingston native. ==Track length== One lap on the track is 400 meters. ==Kingston Colonials== Dietz Stadium was originally built as a football stadium for the local high school, but was repurposed to serve as the home of the revived [[Kingston Colonials (baseball)|Kingston Colonials]], a [[Class B (baseball)|Class B]] baseball team. ==High school football== After the team folded in 1951,[[Kingston Colonials (baseball)]] the stadium was purchased by the City of Kingston for the Kingston City School District, and has served as a high school football stadium ever since. ==Soccer== Dietz Stadium has been the home of [[Kingston Stockade FC]] since 2016. Stockade FC plays in the [[National Premier Soccer League]] (NPSL) and won the North Atlantic White Conference Championship in 2017. ==Professional football== The team served as the home stadium for the short-lived Hudson Valley Highlanders of the North American Football League; the team played only one season in 2008. ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Sports venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:Sports venues in Ulster County, New York]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1949]] [[Category:1949 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Soccer venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:Defunct baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:American football venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:High school football venues in the United States]] [[Category:National Premier Soccer League stadiums]] [[Category:Baseball venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in New York (state)]]

(2015–present) | arena = [[Jezero Hall]] | capacity = 3,750 | location = [[Kragujevac]], Serbia | colors = Red and White
{{color box|#8a1a2c}} {{color box|white}} | president = | coach = [[Bojan Kusmuk]] | championships = | website = [http://www.kkkradnicki.com/ kkkradnicki.com] | h_body=CC0000|h_pattern_b=_thinsidesonwhite|h_shorts=CC0000|h_pattern_s=_blanksides2 | a_body=CC0000|a_pattern_b=_thinwhitesides|a_shorts=CC0000|a_pattern_s=_whitesides }} '''Kragujevački košarkaški klub Radnički''' ({{lang-sr-cyr|Крагујевачки кошаркашки клуб Раднички}}), commonly referred to as '''КKK Radnički''', is a men's professional [[basketball]] [[Sports club|club]] based in [[Kragujevac]], [[Serbia]]. They are currently competing in the [[Basketball League of Serbia]]. == History == The club was founded on October 2015, and former basketball player and Kragujevac-born [[Nikola Lončar]] became the club president.{{cite web|title=Nikola Lončar na čelu projekta KKK Radnički|url=http://www.b92.net/sport/kosarka/vesti.php?yyyy=2015&mm=10&dd=12&nav_id=1050486|website=b92.net|accessdate=9 September 2017}} [[KK Napredak Kruševac|Napredak Rubin]] who competed in the [[Basketball League of Serbia]] in the [[2016–17 Basketball League of Serbia|2016–17 season]] changed the tier with the Radnički for [[2017–18 Basketball League of Serbia season|2017–18 season]]. By approval from [[Basketball Federation of Serbia]], Napredak moved to the [[Serbian basketball league system|3rd-tier]] [[First Regional Basketball League (Serbia)|First Regional League (West)]].{{cite web|title=KKK Radnički - novi član Prve lige Srbije (KLS)|url=http://www.kkkradnicki.com/clanci/iz-kluba/vesti/kkk-radnicki-novi-clan-prve-lige-srbije-kls.html|website=kkkradnicki.com|accessdate=9 September 2017}} {{sr icon}}{{cite web|title=ZAMENA RANGA SA NAPRETKOM: KKK Radnički novi član Prve lige Srbije|url=http://kosarka.hotsport.rs/2017/08/30/zamena-ranga-sa-napretkom-kkk-radnicki-novi-clan-prve-lige-srbije/|website=kosarka.hotsport.rs|accessdate=9 September 2017}} {{sr icon}} == Players == {{also|Category:KKK Radnički players}} ==Season by season== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:85%; text-align:center" !Season !Tier !Division !Pos. !Postseason !{{Tooltip|RS|Regular season record}} !{{Tooltip|PO|Playoff record}} ![[Radivoj Korać Cup]] |- |bgcolor=#efefef|2015–16 | 4 || align=left| [[Second Regional Basketball League (Serbia)|Second Regional (West Group 2)]] | bgcolor=lightblue|1 | {{Tooltip|DNQ|Did not qualify}} | 22–0 | — | ''Did not qualify'' |- |bgcolor=#efefef|2016–17 | 3 || align=left| [[First Regional Basketball League (Serbia)|First Regional (West)]] | 4 | {{Tooltip|DNQ|Did not qualify}} | 20–6 | — | ''Did not qualify'' |- |bgcolor=#efefef|[[2017–18 Basketball League of Serbia|2017–18]] | 1 || align=left| [[Basketball League of Serbia|First League]] | bgcolor=#ffdddd|13 | {{Tooltip|DNQ|Did not qualify}} | 7–19 | — | ''Did not qualify'' |- |} Source: [http://www.srbijasport.net/klub/7846-kkk-radnicki/rez Srbijasport] == Coaching history == {{also|Category:KKK Radnički coaches}} * {{flagicon|SRB}} Nenad Milojević (2015–2016) * {{flagicon|SRB}} Zoran Milovanović (August 2016 – April 2017){{cite web|title=Zoran Milovanović - šef struke KKK Radnički|url=http://www.kkkradnicki.com/clanci/iz-kluba/vesti/zoran-milovanovic-sef-struke-kkk-radnicki.html|website=kkkradnicki.com|accessdate=9 September 2017}}{{cite web|title=UO KKK Radnički prihvatio ostavku Milovanovića|url=http://www.kkkradnicki.com/clanci/iz-kluba/vesti/uo-kkk-radnicki-prihvatio-ostavku-milovanovica.html|website=kkkradnicki.com|accessdate=9 September 2017}} * {{flagicon|SRB}} Darko Brajković (2017) * {{flagicon|SRB}} [[Zoran Todorović (basketball)|Zoran Todorović]] (2017){{cite web|title=KOŠARKA SE VRATILA U KRAGUJEVAC Radnički počeo pripreme, Zoran Todorović novi trener|url=http://sport.blic.rs/kosarka/domaca-kosarka-i-aba/kosarka-se-vratila-u-kragujevac-radnicki-poceo-pripreme-zoran-todorovic-novi-trener/wjhkxdr|website=sport.blic.rs|accessdate=19 September 2017}} * {{flagicon|SRB}} [[Bojan Kusmuk]] (2017–present){{cite web|title=Bojan Kusmuk na čelu stručnog štaba|url=http://www.kkkradnicki.com/clanci/iz-kluba/vesti/bojan-kusmuk-na-celu-strucnog-staba.html|website=kkkradnicki.com|accessdate=9 November 2017}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{official|http://www.kkkradnicki.com/}} {{sr icon}} * [http://basketball.eurobasket.com/team/Serbia/KKK-Radnicki-Kragujevac/15421?Page=0 Team Profile] at eurobasket.com {{KK Radnički Kragujevac}} {{Basketball League of Serbia}} {{Men's Basketball Teams in Serbia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Radnički KKK}} [[Category:KK Radnički Kragujevac]] [[Category:Sport in Kragujevac]] [[Category:Basketball teams in Serbia]] {{Serbia-sport-stub}} {{Europe-basketball-team-stub}}

'''LABR''' was the first high-profile fantasy sports experts league of its kind. Formed by John Hunt, the fantasy baseball columnist for USA Today [[Baseball Weekly]], the league was first formed in 1994 and featured such celebrities as [[Peter Gammons]], [[Keith Olbermann]] and [[Bill James]].<ref name="LABR">{{cite news | first=Jonah | last=[[Jonah Keri|Keri]] | title='Tis the season to project stats | url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/page2/story?page=keri/070214 | publisher=ESPN.com | year=2007 }}</ref> LABR stands for '''League of Alternative Baseball Reality''' and was given that nickname and the pronunciation ("labor") by Olbermann as a play on words with the [[1994 Major League Baseball strike|labor strike]] in baseball at that time.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://content.usatoday.com/communities/fantasywindup/post/2011/02/2011-labr-drafts-are-coming-to-sirius-xm-radio/1?csp=34 | title = 2011 LABR Drafts are coming to Sirius XM Radio | accessdate = 2011-03-07 | last = Gardner | first = Steve | date = Feb 24, 2011 | work = USAToday.com | publisher = Gannett | quote = The name LABR was coined by Olbermann and it played on the unsettled labor situation baseball had at the time. }}</ref> Hunt ran the league and published the results of the LABR league in the ''Baseball Weekly''{{'}}s (now ''USA Today Sports Weekly'') fantasy baseball preview issue each March from 1994 through 2006. He opted not to return for the 2007 league and was replaced with in-house staff. The dollar values players were sold for in the fantasy league are used as a benchmark for readers in their own fantasy drafts.
The LABR has lost its early status as the premier experts' league, as in 1997 a rival fantasy baseball experts league, [[Tout Wars]], was created by [[Ron Shandler]], who was fed up with the lack of promotion USA Today gave the LABR league.<ref>{{cite news | first=Sam | last=Walker | coauthors= | title=Fantasyland | year=2006 | publisher=Viking | url =http://www.fantasyland.com | work = | pages =145 | accessdate = 2007-07-17 | language = }}</ref>
The LABR Mixed league,<ref>{{cite news | coauthors= | title=LABR Mixed | year=2016 | publisher=RealTime Fantasy Sports| url = http://www.rtsports.com/LABR-Mixed | work = | pages = | accessdate = | language = }}</ref> AL-Only league<ref>{{cite news | coauthors= | title=LABR AL| year=2016 | publisher=RealTime Fantasy Sports| url = http://www.rtsports.com/LABR-AL | work = | pages = | accessdate = | language = }}</ref> and NL-Only league<ref>{{cite news | coauthors= | title=LABR NL| year=2016 | publisher=RealTime Fantasy Sports| url = http://www.rtsports.com/LABR-NL | work = | pages = | accessdate = | language = }}</ref> are online and can be viewed by the general public.
==Scoring Rules==
LABR uses a Ranked, Rotisserie Based Scoring System of 5 batting categories and 5 pitching categories (5x5).
If there are N teams in the LABR, N points shall be awarded for first place in a category, N-1 for second place, down to 1 point for last place. In the event of a tie, the points will be split. Points will be aggregated over all ten scoring categories (see below). The team with the most points wins.
Example: LABR has 15 teams. Team A has the most home runs, and is awarded 15 points in that category. Teams B and C are tied for second in home runs; they split the second and third place points, and each receive 13.5 points. If a team finished first in all 10 categories, it would receive a total of 15*10=150 points. If it finished last in all categories, it would receive 1*10=10 points. In the case of ties in total points, the final places in the standings are determined by comparing the placement of the teams in the individual categories. The team ahead in a category is given a point. This is done over all categories. The team with the most points is declared the winner. Should the teams still be tied after this process, then the final result shall be declared a tie.
Batting Categories * Batting Average * Runs * Home Runs * Runs Batted In * Stolen Bases
Pitching Categories * Wins * Earned Run Average * WHIP (Walks+Hits)/(Innings Pitched) * Strikeouts * Saves
Each team will be required to attain a minimum of 950 innings pitched in order to qualify for placement in the pitching categories of; a) Ratio and b) Earned Run Average, and a minimum of 4,200 at-bats for placement in the batting average category. If these minimum innings or at-bats are not achieved the team will receive 1 point in these categories and every team that meets the minimum innings pitched or at-bats will be ranked in the standings with 15 points for 1st place and so on until all qualifying teams have received points.
==Rosters==
Rosters shall consist of a lineup of 23 players and a bench of 6 reserve players.
A team's active roster consists of the following players: 5 outfielders, 2 catchers, 1 second baseman, 1 shortstop, 1 middle infielder (either second baseman or shortstop), 1 first baseman, 1 third baseman, 1 corner infielder (first or third baseman), one utility player who may be of any position and 9 pitchers (who may be either starters, relievers or both).
There will also be six reserve players on each team's roster to be selected on draft day. Players who go onto the disabled list may also be reserved on a separate list. There is no limit to the number of disabled list players that can exist on a roster.
Only members of the active roster generate statistics.
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
'''La Barra Del Rojo''' is the [[barra brava]] of the [[Club Atlético Independiente]]. They are unusual in Argentina in that they do not have a nickname. It is considered as the largest and strongest barra brava in [[Argentina]].<ref>[http://www.ole.com.ar/independiente/duenos-infierno_0_530346984.html Olé]</ref><ref>[http://www.infobae.com/deportes/432666-0-0-Cuentan-c%F3mo-opera-la-barra-Independiente# Infobae]</ref> The existence of this group has been publicly known since the 1950s. Besides attending Independiente matches, since 1982, the core members of the group attend the [[Argentina national football team|national team]]'s [[FIFA World Cup|World Cups]]. They also attended some times the [[Copa América]].
== Composition == Although La Barra Del Rojo work as a united group, it consists of a large number of sub-groups, which come from neighborhoods throughout [[Avellaneda]], the rest of the [[Greater Buenos Aires]], [[Buenos Aires]], [[La Plata]] and the [[Greater La Plata]]. These sub-groups generally carry the names of their neighborhoods or cities of origin, or the nicknames of their bosses. The most important are: ''Fiorito'', ''La Tranquila'', ''La Banda de San Justo'', ''Los Polacos'', ''Los camioneros'', ''Villa Corina'', ''Los Rana'', ''Los Bera'', ''Los Narigones'', ''Los Gerlis'', ''La 4 de Julio'', ''La Pepsi'', etc.; all of them come from the most dangerous ''[[villa miseria|villas miserias]]'' and poor neighborhoods of cities like [[Avellaneda]], [[Buenos Aires]], [[San Justo, Buenos Aires|San Justo]], [[Berazategui]], [[Sarandí, Buenos Aires|Sarandí]], [[Merlo, Buenos Aires|Merlo]], [[Villa Domínico]], [[Wilde, Buenos Aires|Wilde]], [[Lanús]], [[Claypole, Buenos Aires|Claypole]], [[Quilmes]], [[Villa Fiorito]], [[Lomas de Zamora]], [[Banfield, Buenos Aires|Banfield]], [[La Plata]], etc.
Within the barra brava, there is a pecking order.<ref>[http://www.efdeportes.com/efd55/client.htm EF y Deportes]</ref> The "first line", consisting in fewer than 10 persons, is formed by the bosses (headed by the leader), who are the chiefs of the major sub-groups. A requisite for becoming a boss is to have been a member of the group for at least 10 years. They are responsible for the organization and the distribution of money and tasks within the barra brava. The "second line", ranging from 15 to 30 people, is formed by the chiefs and important members of the rest of the sub-groups. They take care of recruiting people, study the area and the movements of the enemy barras bravas, and hire buses for the transfer of group members. The "third line", consisting of about 400 people, it consists of the following members in the range, behind the leaders in each sub-groups. They already have some years in the barra brava, but are not yet part of the core. They handle the drums and flags. The "fourth line", or rest of the barra brava, (over 1000 people), is responsible simply to follow the above "lines", and can not make decisions. Everybody is in a sub-group and when there is a fight against another barra brava; all the "lines" must participate.
Most members of La Barra Del Rojo form part of the [[working class]]. The current leader of the barra brava is Pablo "Bebote" ("Big Baby") Álvarez, who took the lead in 2004.
== Financing ==
Their main means of financing include the resale of tickets, drugs,<ref>[http://pdf.diariohoy.net/2000/06/27/pdf/u08.pdf Hoy]</ref> the role of one sub-group as "shock troop" for some political unions ([[General Confederation of Labour (Argentina)|CGT]]<ref>[http://www.pagina12.com.ar/diario/elpais/1-74830-2006-10-20.html Página/12]</ref> and the Syndicate of Truck Drivers), and threatening the directors and players of the club.<ref>[http://edant.clarin.com/diario/especiales/violenciaenelfutbol/nota8/d-06402.htm Clarín]</ref>
According to 2006 research reports, "Polaco" (the chief of the sub-group ''Los Polacos'' and one of the leaders of Los Diablos Rojos) was the bodyguard of [[Hugo Moyano]] (the secretary general of the CGT) 15 years ago and still holds that role.<ref>[http://www.perfil.com/contenidos/2006/10/22/noticia_0015.html Perfil]</ref>
In 2003, an investigation said that the barra brava earned between 40000 and 45000 [[Argentine peso|pesos]] per month.<ref>[http://www.pagina12.com.ar/diario/deportes/8-29024-2003-12-07.html Página/12]</ref>
== Violence == During its existence, the barra brava has had several fights and altercations with the Argentine police<ref>[http://www.continental.com.ar/nota.aspx?id=893596 Continental]</ref> and with other barras bravas, especially with that of [[Racing Club de Avellaneda|Racing de Avellaneda]] (La Guardia Imperial), Independiente's main football rival; it also had major confrontations with the barras bravas of Boca Juniors (La 12), River Plate ([[Los Borrachos del Tablón]]) and [[San Lorenzo de Almagro]] (La Gloriosa), also rivals of the club. However, any barra brava of other team is targeted as an enemy, even if there is no football-related rivalry.
On 17 October 2006, during the procession for the transfer of the coffin of ex-president [[Juan Domingo Perón]] from the [[La Chacarita Cemetery|La Chacarita]] cemetery (in the city of [[Buenos Aires]]) to a mausoleum in a summer residence in [[San Vicente, Buenos Aires|San Vicente]], some members of La Barra Del Rojo became involved (among them Jorge "Madonna" Quiroz)<ref>[http://www.26noticias.com.ar/investigan-la-participacion-de-barrabravas-en-los-incidentes-de-san-vicente-24497.html 26 Noticias]</ref> in a fight instigated by Peronist trade unions over access to the ceremony (some sub-groups of the barra brava belong to the CGT and the Syndicate of Truck Drivers, both Peronist). Is believed that the fight started because there were several members of the barras bravas of [[Estudiantes de La Plata]] and [[Defensores de Cambaceres]] in the UOCRA (another Peronist union then present). The police were able to contain the violence enough for the ceremony to finish.
In 1997, a member of La Barra Del Rojo was indicted for the murder of Walter Rodríguez,<ref>[http://edant.clarin.com/diario/1997/10/08/e-05701d.htm Clarín]</ref> and in 2001, the death of another fan of Racing Club<ref>[http://edant.clarin.com/diario/2002/02/19/d-03401.htm Clarín]</ref> was attributed to the barra brava. Both victims were members of La Guardia Imperial.
In 2004 in [[Quito]], [[Ecuador]], the barra brava fought the Ecuadorian police during a [[2004 Copa Libertadores|Copa Libertadores]] match between [[Club Deportivo El Nacional|El Nacional]] and Independente in the [[Estadio Olímpico Atahualpa|Atahualpa]] stadium. As a result of the incident, two supporters of Independiente was arrested. They were released two days later.<ref>[http://edant.clarin.com/diario/2004/03/17/um/m-726092.htm Clarín]</ref>
== See also == *[[Club Atlético Independiente]] *[[Barra brava]] *[[Football hooliganism]]

{{Infobox stadium |stadium_name= Lakeview Arena |nickname= |image= |location= 401 East Fair Avenue
Marquette, Michigan |broke_ground= |opened= 1974 |closed= |demolished= |owner= City of Marquette |operator= Parks and Recreation Department |surface= {{convert|200|x|85|ft|m}} (hockey)| |construction_cost= |architect= |former_names= |tenants={{plainlist|1= *[[Marquette Iron Rangers]] ([[United States Hockey League|USHL]]) (1974–1976) *[[Northern Michigan Wildcats]] ([[NCAA]]) (1976–1999) *[[Marquette Rangers]] ([[North American Hockey League|NAHL]]) (2006–2010) *Marquette Mutineers ([[Great Lakes Hockey League (adult)|GLHL]]) (2015–present) }} |seating_capacity = 3,100 (hockey) }} '''Lakeview Arena''' is a 3,100-seat multi-purpose arena, located in [[Marquette, Michigan]]. It opened in 1974, during the Marquette Iron Rangers hockey season. The team had previously played in the historic [[Palestra (Michigan)|Palestra]], a building that had moved from [[Laurium, Michigan]] in 1921 and was torn down shortly after Lakeview opened. From 1976 to 1999, it was the home of [[Northern Michigan University]]'s hockey program, and it was there, during the 1990–91 season, that the Wildcats posted a perfect home record on their way to the [[1991 NCAA Division I Men's Ice Hockey Tournament]]. [[Kiss (band)|KISS]] performed at the arena during their [[Animalize Tour]] on March 20, 1985, during their [[Crazy Nights Tour]] on January 5, 1988, and during their [[Hot in The Shade Tour]] on October 4, 1990. Today, the building is used for local hockey programs, as well as other events and conventions in the city. It was also home to the [[Michigan Warriors|Marquette Rangers]] of the [[NAHL]] between 2006 and 2010, before they moved to [[Flint, Michigan|Flint]]. It became home to the newly revived [[Marquette Iron Rangers]] in the [[Great Lakes Hockey League (adult)|Great Lakes Hockey League]]'s 2015-16 season."[http://marquettesocialscene.com/marquette-approved-for-expansion-glhl-franchise/ Marquette Approved for Expansion GLHL Franchise]," ''MQT Social Scene'', April 25, 2015. After that season, the team changed its name to the Mutineers. Lakeview is owned by the city and operated by the Parks and Recreation Department. Lakeview won the [[Kraft Hockeyville]] USA contest on April 30, 2016. The arena received $150,000 in upgrades, and hosted the [[Buffalo Sabres]] and [[Carolina Hurricanes]] on October 4, 2016 in a preseason [[NHL]] contest. Buffalo won the game 2-0.{{cite web | url=https://www.nhl.com/news/hockeyville-usa-2016-winner-is-marquette-mich/c-280524324 | title=Marquette, Mich., wins Kraft Hockeyville USA 2016 | publisher=NHL.com | date=April 30, 2016 | accessdate=April 30, 2016}} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.mqtcty.org/parks_arena.html Lakeview Arena at the City of Marquette website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20010613141210/http://www.marquetteironrangers.com/lastgame.htm Link to ''Mining Journal'' article on final game at Palestra] {{coord|46.557257|-87.386832|display=t|type:landmark}} {{NAHL Arenas}} [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in the United States]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Marquette, Michigan]] [[Category:Sports venues in Michigan]] [[Category:Defunct college ice hockey venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1974]]

page.title: List of athletes who competed in both the Summer and Winter Olympic games

revision.text:
Below is a '''list of athletes who competed in both the Summer and Winter Olympics''', as of the end of the [[2016 Summer Olympic Games]].<ref name=Brennan>{{cite news|last=Brennan|first=Danielle|title=Double duty: 11 Olympians who've played both winter and summer sports|url=http://www.today.com/sochi/double-duty-11-athletes-whove-competed-both-winter-summer-olympics-2D11960556|accessdate=22 February 2014|newspaper=[[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today Show]]|date=21 January 2014}}</ref>
Prior to the [[1924 Winter Olympic Games|first winter games in 1924]], the [[winter sports]] of [[Figure skating at the Olympic Games|Figure skating]] and [[Ice hockey at the Olympic Games|Ice hockey]] had been contested in the Summer Olympics. The creation of the first winter games allowed for many athletes of the era to compete in both sets of games in the same discipline,<ref name="Watt "/> and on this page these athletes are listed [[#Athletes who competed in both Summer and Winter Olympics in the same sport|below the main list]]. The Russian athlete [[Nikolai Panin]] is unique in having competed in both a summer sport ([[Shooting at the Summer Olympics|shooting]] in [[1912 Olympic Games|1912]]) and a winter sport (figure skating in [[1908 Olympic Games|1908]]) but only competing at the Summer Olympics.<ref name=SR72>{{cite web|title=Nikolai Panin|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/ko/nikolay-kolomenkin-1.html|publisher=Sports Reference|accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref>
Among these athletes, the most-occurring combination is [[Bobsleigh|bobsledding]] and [[Athletics (sport)|athletics]], followed by [[cycling]] and [[speed skating]].<ref name="Olympicstats">{{cite web|url=http://olympstats.com/2014/01/07/summer-winter-olympic-sports-doubles/|title=SUMMER / WINTER OLYMPIC SPORTS DOUBLES|first=Bill|last=Mallon|date=7 January 2014|publisher=OlympStats}}</ref> Other events competed in by Summer and Winter Olympians include [[fencing]], [[track and field]], [[sailing]], [[ski jumping]], and [[Equestrianism|equestrian]] events. Only five of the 136 athletes [[List of Olympians who have won medals in both the Summer and Winter Olympics|won medals]] in both the Summer or Winter Olympics.<ref name="Olympicstats"/><ref name="Adelson">{{cite web |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/lauryn-williams--lolo-jones-make-history-with-bobsled-runs-155706619.html|title=Lauryn Williams, Lolo Jones make history with bobsled runs; U.S. in first, third place|first=Eric|last=Adelson|date=18 February 2014|accessdate=6 March 2014|work=Yahoo! Sports}}</ref> [[Eddie Eagan]] was the only athlete to win gold medals in both the Summer and Winter Olympics.<ref name="Olympicstats"/><ref name=Adelson/> Some of the Olympians [[List of athletes with the most appearances at Olympic Games|competed in both sets of games]] over a span of different decades.
==Athletes who competed in both Summer and Winter Olympics==
{| class="wikitable" |- | style="text-align:center; background:#b6fcb6;"| |Denotes athlete who has won medals in both the Summer and Winter Olympics |}

[[File:Steve arndt cd.jpg|thumb|upright=1.14|The [[Arndt Magic Dragon]] microlift glider at Harris Hill, N.Y. The Magic Dragon is a development of the [[Carbon Dragon]] design.]]
A '''microlift glider''' is a recreational [[Glider aircraft|glider]] that is able to exploit microlift, which is [[lift (soaring)|lift]] weaker than a conventional [[Glider (sailplane)|glider]] would require to stay airborne.
==Classification== The [[Fédération Aéronautique Internationale]] [[FAI Gliding Commission|Gliding Commission]]'s Sporting Code defines the [[Glider Competition Classes|classes]] for [[gliding competitions]] and records. One of the classes is the ultralight glider. These are defined as gliders with a take-off mass not exceeding 220 kg (486 lb). Examples of these are the [[Albastar Apis WR|Apis]] and [[Alisport Silent 2|Silent 2]]. Microlift gliders are a sub-type of the ultralight class, further defined by a [[wing loading]] that does not exceed 18 kg/m² (3.69 lb/ft<sup>2</sup>).These definitions were adopted for inclusion in the Sporting Code, Section 3, [[Gliding]], effective on October 1, 2004.<ref name="FAI1">{{cite web|url = http://www.fai.org/gliding/sc3.1.0#4|title = FAI Sporting Code|accessdate = 6 April 2012|last = [[Fédération Aéronautique Internationale]]|date = n.d. |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080621012626/http://www.fai.org/gliding/sc3.1.0 |archivedate = 21 June 2008}}</ref>
World records for the ultralight class have been recognized by the FAI but there are no [[World Gliding Championships|World Championships]] for these types at present. For world records microlift gliders are classed with the other ultralight gliders and/or hang gliders.<ref name="FAI1" />
The FAI has produced a loaded weight versus wing loading diagram defining the different domains for glider classes.<ref name="FAI2">{{cite web|url = http://www.fai.org/gliding/documents/microlift.pdf|title = Development of the Microlift Glider|accessdate = 6 April 2012|last = Morelli|first = Piero|date = 16 September 2004 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090227193024/http://www.fai.org/gliding/documents/microlift.pdf |archivedate = 27 February 2009}}</ref>
==Characteristics== In addition to the traditional [[Lift (soaring)|forms of lift]] used in the sport of [[gliding]], microlift gliding also aims to exploit non-traditional sources of weak lift. In typical conditions, conventional [[sailplane]]s may be unable to exploit weak vertical movements of air. However a microlift glider that is specifically designed to have a very low rate of sink and a very small circling radius, may be able to exploit these feeble air movements for sustained flight and may even allow the glider to climb.<ref>''OSTIV Sailplane Development Panel of the Microlift Glider'' by Piero Morelli.</ref><ref>Gary Osoba, Toward a 20 Hour Work-Week – Sailplane Builder, July 1995.</ref>
==Microlift gliders == [[Image:Lighthawk.jpg|250px|thumb|right|The [[Glidersport LightHawk]], with its complex wing design.]] *[[Advanced Aeromarine Sierra]] *[[Aériane Swift]] *[[Bailey-Moyes Tempest]] *[[EEL ULF 1]] *[[Glidersport LightHawk]] *[[Maupin Carbon Dragon]] *[[Ruppert Archaeopteryx]]
